statement.p:
Consider the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp -1 \amp 1 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 1 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Explain why A has an inverse.
Find the inverse of A by augmenting by the identity I to form \left[\begin{array}{r|r}A \amp I \end{array}\right].
Use your inverse to solve the equation A\xvec = \fourvec{3}{2}{-3}{-1}.

li.p: We see that A\sim I, the identity matrix, which implies that A has an inverse.

statement.p:
In this exercise, we will consider 2\times 2 matrices as defining linear transformations.
Write the matrix A that performs a 45^\circ rotation. What geometric operation undoes this rotation? Find the matrix that perform this operation and verify that it is A^{-1}.
Write the matrix A that performs a 180^\circ rotation. Verify that A^2 = I so that A^{-1} = A, and explain geometrically why this is the case.
Find three more matrices A that satisfy A^2 = I.

li.p: A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp -\frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \end{array}\right]. To undo the rotation, we will perform a 45^\circ clockwise rotation, which is defined by the matrix A^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ -\frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \end{array}\right].
A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]. We see that A^2=I because rotating by 180^\circ is its own inverse.

We can do this by constructing matrices that define reflections, such as
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp -\frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \end{array}\right] and A^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ -\frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \end{array}\right].
A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right].

statement.p:
Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix.
Suppose that A^2 = AA is invertible with inverse B. This means that BA^2 = BAA = I. Explain why A must be invertible with inverse BA.
Suppose that A^{100} is invertible with inverse B. Explain why A is invertible. What is A^{-1} in terms of A and B?

li.p: If A^2 has inverse B, then BA^2 = I. This means that (BA)A=I so A is invertible with inverse BA.
In the same way, we have BA^{100} = (BA^{99})A=I, which shows that A^{-1}=BA^{99}.
If A^2 has inverse B, then BA^2 = I. This means that (BA)A=I so A is invertible with inverse BA.
In the same way, we have BA^{100} = (BA^{99})A=I, which shows that A^{-1}=BA^{99}.

statement.p:
Our definition of an invertible matrix requires that A be a square n\times n matrix. Let's examine what happens when A is not square. For instance, suppose that
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp -1 \\ -2 \amp -1 \\ 3 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right], \hspace{24pt} B = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -2 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Verify that BA = I_2. In this case, we say that B is a left inverse of A.
If A has a left inverse B, we can still use it to find solutions to linear equations. If we know there is a solution to the equation A\xvec = \bvec, we can multiply both sides of the equation by B to find \xvec = B\bvec.
Suppose you know there is a solution to the equation A\xvec = \threevec{-1}{-3}{6}. Use the left inverse B to find \xvec and verify that it is a solution.
Now consider the matrix
C = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] and verify that C is also a left inverse of A. This shows that the matrix A may have more than one left inverse.
When A is a square matrix, we said that BA=I implies that AB=I. In this problem, we have a non-square matrix A with BA = I. What happens when we compute AB?

li.p: We compute that BA=I_2.
We find \xvec=B\threevec{-1}{-3}{6} = \twovec{2}{-1}, which is indeed a solution to the equation A\xvec=\threevec{-1}{-3}{6}.
In the same way, we compute CA=I_2.
In this example, the product AB is a 3\times3 matrix, which is different than the identity. This shows that A is not a left-inverse of B.
BA=I_2.
CA=I_2.
A is not a left-inverse of B.

statement.p:
If a matrix A is invertible, there is a sequence of row operations that transform A into the identity matrix I. We have seen that every row operation can be performed by matrix multiplication. If the j^{th} step in the Gaussian elimination process is performed by multiplying by E_j, then we have
E_p\ldots E_2E_1 A = I , which means that
A^{-1} = E_p\ldots E_2E_1 . For each of the following matrices, find a sequence of row operations that transforms the matrix to the identity I. Write the matrices E_j that perform the steps and use them to find A^{-1}.
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] .

li.p:
We use a scaling followed by replacement operations:
S = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp \frac12 \\ \end{array}\right], U_1 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], U_2 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}
This gives U_2U_1SA = I so that
A^{-1} = U_2U_1S = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -\frac12 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp \frac12 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A^{-1}= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp -\frac13 \amp 0 \\ \frac12 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A^{-1} = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -6 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 12 \amp -6 \amp -2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
A^{-1} = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -\frac12 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp \frac12 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and explain your reasoning.
If A is invertible, then the columns of A are linearly independent.
If A is a square matrix whose diagonal entries are all nonzero, then A is invertible.
If A is an invertible n\times n matrix, then the columns of A span \real^n.
If A is invertible, then there is a nontrivial solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec.
If A is an n\times n matrix and the equation A\xvec = \bvec has a solution for every vector \bvec, then A is invertible.

li.p: True. If A is invertible, then it has a pivot position in every column, which implies that the columns are linearly independent.
False. We only know this if A is a triangular matrix. For instance, the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] is not invertible.
True. If A is invertible, then it has a pivot position in every row, which implies that the columns span \real^n.
False. Since there is a pivot position in every column, the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec has only the trivial solution \xvec=\zerovec.
True. In this case, the columns of A span \real^n so there must be a pivot position in every row. Because A is a square matrix, it must be row equivalent to the identity matrix I.
True
False
True
False
True

statement.p:
Provide a justification for your response to the following questions.
Suppose that A is a square matrix with two identical columns. Can A be invertible?
Suppose that A is a square matrix with two identical rows. Can A be invertible?
Suppose that A is an invertible matrix and that AB = AC. Can you conclude that B = C?
Suppose that A is an invertible n\times n matrix. What can you say about the span of the columns of A^{-1}?
Suppose that A is an invertible matrix and that B is row equivalent to A. Can you guarantee that B is invertible?

li.p: No. If A has two identical columns, then the columns are not linearly independent. This means there is a column without a pivot position and so A is not row equivalent to the identity matrix I.

No. If we perform a replacement operation that multiplies one of the equal rows by -1 and adds it to the other equal row, we obtain a matrix having a row whose entries are all zero. This says that the reduced row echelon form has such a row as well. Therefore, there is a row that does not contain a pivot so the reduced row echelon form cannot be the identity I.
Yes. If we multiply both sides of AB=AC by A^{-1} on the left, then we see that B=C.
The inverse A^{-1} is also invertible since A is its inverse. Therefore, the span of the columns of A^{-1} is \real^n.
Yes. Since A is row equivalent to the identity matrix I, the matrix B is as well. Therefore, B is invertible.
No
No
Yes
The span is \real^n.
Yes

statement.p:
Suppose that we start with the 3\times3 matrix A and perform the following sequence of row operations:
Multiply row 1 by -2 and add to row 2.
Multiply row 1 by 4 and add to row 3.
Scale row 2 by 1/2.
Multiply row 2 by -1 and add to row 3.
Suppose we arrive at the upper triangular matrix
U = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -4 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Write the matrices E_1, E_2, E_3, and E_4 that perform the four row operations.
Find the matrix E = E_4E_3E_2E_1.
We then have E_4E_3E_2E_1 A = EA = U. Now that we have the matrix E, find the original matrix A = E^{-1}U.

li.p:
We have
\begin{array}{cc} E_1=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right], \amp E_2=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right], \\ E_3 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right], \amp E_4 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{array}
We have E = E_4E_3E_2E_1 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp 0 \\ 5 \amp -\frac12 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] .
We write A=E^{-1}U= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 6 \amp 6 \amp 4 \\ -12 \amp -7 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] .

We have
\begin{array}{cc} E_1=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right], \amp E_2=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right], \\ E_3 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right], \amp E_4 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{array}
E = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp 0 \\ 6 \amp -1 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] .
A= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 6 \amp 6 \amp 4 \\ -12 \amp -6 \amp 6 \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
We defined an n\times n matrix to be invertible if there is a matrix B such that BA=I_n. In this exercise, we will explain why B is also invertible and that AB = I. This means that, if B=A^{-1}, then A = B^{-1}.
Given the fact that BA = I_n, explain why the matrix B must also be a square n\times n matrix.
Suppose that \bvec is a vector in \real^n. Since we have BA = I, it follows that B(A\bvec) = \bvec. Use this to explain why the columns of B span \real^n. What does this say about the pivot positions of B?
Explain why the equation B\xvec = \zerovec has only the trivial solution.
Beginning with the equation, BA=I, multiply both sides by B to obtain BAB = B. We will rearrange this equation:
\begin{aligned} BAB \amp {}={} B \\ BAB - B\amp {}={} 0 \\ B(AB-I) \amp {}={} 0\text{.} \\ \end{aligned}
Since the homogeneous equation B\xvec =\zerovec has only the trivial solution, explain why AB-I = 0 and therefore, AB = I.

li.p: Since BA is defined, B must have n columns. And since BA has n rows, B must have n rows. This means that B is a square n\times n matrix.
Every row of B must have a pivot position, which means that B is row equivalent to the identity matrix I.
Because every row of B has a pivot position, every column of B does as well. Therefore, the homogeneous equation B\xvec=\zerovec has only the trivial solution \xvec=\zerovec.

If we choose any vector \yvec, we have B(AB-I)\yvec = B[(AB-I)\yvec]=\zerovec. Therefore, (AB-I)\yvec is a solution to the homogeneous equation B\xvec=\zerovec, and we can conclude that (AB-I)\yvec = \zerovec. This means that AB\yvec - \yvec = \zerovec or AB\yvec = \yvec for every vector \yvec. Therefore, AB=I, which shows that B^{-1} = A.
Because BA is defined and has n rows.
Every row of B must have a pivot position.
Every column of B must have a pivot position.
B[(AB-I)\yvec] = \zerovec for any \yvec, which means that (AB-I)\yvec for any \yvec. This says that AB=I.
